title: Other outcome variables
text:
Behavioral measures

Donation
To assess consequential and impactful behavior, participants will be given the option to donate a monetary bonus to the American Geophysical Union (AGU), or keep it for themselves. The AGU was chosen because it is the leading scientific association for scientists working on climate change. Participants read following:


â€œFor the next question, we would like you to have the opportunity to donate money to a non-profit or to keep it for yourself. Please decide how you would like to allocate $10 between yourself and the American Geophysical Union (AGU). The AGU is a non-profit, non-partisan scientific association. It is the largest scientific association in the area of climate change in the US, with over 15,000 scientist members. You can give all of the money to the AGU and keep none for yourself, or you can keep all the money for yourself and give none to AGU, or you can pick any split in between. Note: We will randomly select a subset of 100 participants and realize their choices.â€

section: Normative perceptions & Willingness to be vulnerable
text:
Normative perceptions & Willingness to be vulnerable
[General consideration: normative perceptions, here, really are for the most part about scientists influence on public policy. It would make sense to have a more meaningful, less abstract name.]
Scales were adapted from XX, but slightly modified. For example, for the normative perception measure, we removed one item (â€œClimate scientists should be more involved in the policy-making processâ€) as it was extremely close to the first item of the scale.
For the willingness to be vulnerable measure, we retained only one item, as the other two (â€œHow much or little should governments rely on climate scientistsâ€™ guidance when making decisions related to climate science?â€ and â€œHow much or little control do you want climate scientists to have on government decisions related to science?â€) were very close conceptually to the normative perception measures.

title: Now launched: Call for Collaboration
text:
ğŸ¤ Collaborate with us!
The Strengthening Trust in Climate Scientists Megastudy is a collaborative research project to be run in the United States.
We invite researchers at any career stageâ€”from students to principal investigatorsâ€”as well as practitioners to submit intervention ideas.
Successful contributors will receive co-authorship in the primary publication arising from this project.
Interventions can be submitted by individuals or teams, with a maximum of two individuals per team. Each team may propose up to two interventions, which will be evaluated independently.


ğŸ” What Weâ€™re Looking For
We are seeking short, text-based informational interventions that could increase trust in climate scientists.
The most promising interventions will be selected and tested in a megastudyâ€”a large-scale online experiment designed for robust, replicable results.
ğŸ‘‰ Learn about submission rules and how to contribute on our Call for Collaborations page.

title: Research Design
text:
While trust in scientists is moderately high globally (Cologna et al. 2025), climate scientists have consistently been found to be less trusted than scientists from other fields and scientists in general (Druckman et al. 2024; Ghasemi et al. 2025; SchrÃ¸der 2023; Schug, Bilandzic, and Kinnebrock 2024). Lower trust in climate scientists could hamper societiesâ€™ ability to address climate change, resulting in high personal and societal costs.
Strengthening trust in climate scientists matters: Across 55 countries, trust in climate scientists was the strongest predictor of belief in climate change and support for climate policy (Todorova et al. 2025).
Increasing trust in climate scientists may therefore be an important lever to accelerate climate action and strengthen societal resilience to climate change. There is currently only a small number of behavioral intervention studies on increasing trust in climate scientists. The Strengthening Trust in Climate Scientists Megastudy aims to fill this gap.
